newsitem.title: HUNGARY: Buying side cautious on Budapest grains market.
newsitem.headline: Buying side cautious on Budapest grains market.

text.p: Trade in grains futures on the Budapest Commodity Exchange (BCE) dropped to a meagre 190.75 million forints on Thursday due to a very cautious buying side, traders said.

"Sales for new (1997) crop milling wheat and old (1996) crop maize were so far euphoric, but most of it was speculative" said Istvan Markus of Swap brokerage. "It is natural that any sign of a price rise prompts the closing of positions."
New crop wheat maturities opened lower but firmed by the close, he said.
March maturity milling wheat prices rose 100 forints to 25,100 forints per tonne, as some speculators sought to close their positions.
Markus added that most of the remaining open March contracts for milling wheat and maize were probably backed up by actual deliveries.
There are 2,735 open contracts for March maize and 1,016 for milling wheat.
Despite a shortage of barley, feed barley prices dropped by the daily 400 forints limit for all maturities from May to September and Markus said barley prices remain highly unpredictable.
"Feed barley now follows earlier drops in other commodities with a phase delay, but seems to have a mind of its own," he said.
He added that this year's planted area is the smallest in the last 10 years but the dramatic drop in sow livestock also means a reduced feed demand.
"Also, Hungarian feed mixes traditionally contain only a small percentage of barley, thus its price is not so critical," he said.
Total turnover on Thursday was 495 contracts of which 248 were for milling wheat.
Lot size is 20,000 kgs for all contracts.
